title.narrative: 6.3 IMPROVED PARTNERSHIPS WITH AND BETWEEN NATIONAL INSTITUTIONS AND OTHERS FOR S

description.narrative: 6.3 By 2022 improved partnerships with and between national institutions and civil society to promote policy change for children., which contributes to Reducing Child Poverty, Reducing Child Poverty (Covid), Social Protection. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 6. By 2022, children benefit from strengthened policies and programmes that address child poverty, vulnerability and exclusion.

participating-org.narrative: EKDARA GA PA GA KA PA OFFICE

sector.narrative: Contributing to policies reducing child poverty: Poverty reduction strategies, national development plans, engagement with ministries, parliament, international donor and financial organizations, civil society organizations)
Coordination and delivery of social services at local level (urban and rural)
PF4C: Engagement with budget processes to improve social sector budgets (sufficiency, efficiency, effectiveness, transparency, equity)
PF4C: Strengthened capacity of stakeholders in budgeting
Social protection and welfare services policy, planning and administration
Technical assistance - Child poverty, Public Finance and Local Governance

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 6.3 By 2022 improved partnerships with and between national institutions and civil society to promote policy change for children.

description.narrative: Based on enhanced evidence through studies such those related to PF4C, disability and secondary impact of COVID, engagement with parliamentarians, Ministry of Finance, CSOs, (NFDN et al), UN and development partners, continued to strengthen in 2021. Budget briefs produced in 2021 on education, health has been well received by policy makers. All this has contributed to demonstrable strengthening of poverty sensitive inter-governmental transfers and an increase in allocation of budgets to social protection, including revision of the benefit amount. Political instability with the parliament in limbo for extended period is hampered plans to strengthen the partnership initiated in 2020. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:06/01/2022
